courseDescription:
Are you ready for hybrid workplaces? Today’s workplaces look quite different from those before the Covid-19 pandemic. The new culture of working from home gained prominence during various lockdowns and today’s organisations are looking at ways to establish new norms for hybrid teams. However, most of the leadership styles are accustomed to in-office collaborations. How can you collaborate effectively with hybrid teams and hold your team members accountable while working remotely? Most research on psychology, cognitive neuroscience and behavioural economics reveals that we cannot trust our gut feeling or natural reaction to working with hybrid teams. This course will highlight the emerging trends in employees' expectations and what employees want. It guides you through the essentials of making the right calls while leading hybrid teams to achieve organisational objectives. You will first learn about the facts and realities of modern workplaces and then study the best practices used by the leaders of Fortune 500 firms.

How do you lead a remote team effectively? Discover the specific steps that you need to take to adapt to the new normal. These steps have been developed by acquiring inputs from Fortune 500 organisations. How can we maximise our business objective in the post-Covid world? Where do the leaders make errors in judgement? You will learn about the hybrid-first model and the cognitive biases that lead to common managerial judgement errors. Fortune 500 companies have managed to defeat these biases. Their leaders have learnt the art of hybrid collaboration and serendipitous innovation. The best practices of these companies will enable you to develop your own plan and lead with confidence. You will explore the team-led approach. What is the best strategy for funding home offices and redefining office spaces for hybrid work? The additional learning resource available in the course will help you master the skills for managing employee retention, engagement and productivity in a hybrid work atmosphere.

Finally, you will become acquainted with the most promising practices in the context of the future of hybrid work. How can hybrid teams be trained and mentored? You will learn about your employees' critical aspects of performance evaluation and upskilling in a hybrid work atmosphere. You will come across colleagues who are unwilling to adapt to the changing leadership styles. How do you handle such irrational thinking? This course draws on the best practices of Fortune 500 companies and behavioural science techniques. You will investigate a valuable and practical technique called EGRIP (which stands for ‘emotions, goals, rapport, information and positive reinforcement’) to deal with colleagues in denial. Business leaders in the present times have to deal with uncertainty even more. The hybrid work culture demands that the leaders build their skills to manage and preserve the company culture, profitability and human resources. This course will equip you with the necessary mindset and tools to look beyond the perceived ‘compromise’ created by flexible work hours and offices. Enrol today for this course and learn from the best!

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are: 
    • Pandemic spurred major shifts in values and preferences.
    • It is easy to assume that we know what employees want. This is due to mental blindspots called cognitive biases.
    • The false consensus effect is a cognitive bias that makes us think that those in our ‘tribe’ share our beliefs. This is often a false assumption.
    • Avoid judgement errors: Employers should avoid making hasty assumptions. They should examine objective data and insights.
    • Survey results show that employees want to continue working remotely. Over two-thirds (75%) want to work remotely half the time or more. 25% of employees want to work from home full time.
    • Some telework issues are: Funding is needed for home offices and equipment, poor virtual communication and collaboration are an obstacle.
    • There are many reasons why telework will not be discontinued. Companies have made big investments in IT for remote work. Employers and employees have spent money and resources for home offices. There has been a whopping reduction in telework stigma.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are: 
    • A team-led approach is the best return to office plan.
    • To make the transition to hybrid work, take an anonymous survey on preferences, overcome cognitive biases, redefine office spaces.
    • Provide broad, but flexible guidelines for hybrid work. Let the team leaders determine what works best.
    • Overcoming cognitive biases for in-office work includes treating remote work as the default.
    • Realities of hybrid workspace include: In-office space will transform from individual workspace to shared space; much lower expenses for maintaining office spaces.
    • Anticipate regular office space needs by conducting surveys to identify employee preferences.
    • Assess other office space needs for cross-functional teams, training, mass events.
    • Consider a contract with a coworking space for overflow needs.
    • Make transition by allocating budget for home offices. Consider budget for hotspot plans, membership fees for coworking space.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points that were covered in this module are:
    • The reasons why leaders worry about hybrid and remote work are: (i) It undermines new employee integration, (ii) it adversely affects on-the-job learning for junior employees, (iii) cross-functional collaboration is impacted negatively, (iv) organisational culture is degraded.
    • When the leaders did not adopt best practices for leading remote teams during the lockdown, it resulted in difficulties with (i) new employee integration, (ii) junior new employee on-the-job learning, (iii) cross-functional collaboration, (iv) organisational culture.
    • Focus on the hybrid model of work because it optimises collaboration and boosts the retention of top talent.
    • Facilitate remote training through digital coworking.
    • Encourage mutual support in digital coworking.
    • Digital coworking replicates the experience of working in shared cubicles.
    • Facilitate cultural integration and team collaboration through virtual mentoring.
    • Traditional performance evaluation is poorly suited for hybrid and remote work because it relies on the supervisor’s perception or assessment of the time spent working (by the employee). In a hybrid setup, the supervisor cannot see the employee.
